I: I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: that ware posies of her own hand-making

I: I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: that mine own name in the chimneys read

I: By Myra finely wrought ere I was waking :
Must I look on
With change bring back my turn again to play?
I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: that on Sunday at the church-stile found

I: A garland sweet with true-love knots in flowers
Which I to wear about mine arms was bound
That each of us might know that all was ours :
Must I lead now an idle life in wishes
And follow Cupid for his loaves and fishes?
I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: that did wear the ring her mother left

I: I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: for whose love she gloried to be blamed

I: I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: with whose eyes her eyes committed theft

I: I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: who did make her blush when I was named :

I: Must I lose ring
Watching with sighs till dead love be awakèd ?
I
WITH whose colors Myra dressed her head: that when drowsy Argus fell asleep

I: Like Jealousy o'erwatchèd with Desire
Was ever warnèd modesty to keep
While her breath speaking kindled Nature's fire :
Must I look on a-cold while others warm them ?
Do Vulcan's brothers in such fine nets arm them ?
Was it for this that I might Myra see
Washing the water with her beauties white ?
Yet would she never write her love to me :
Thinks wit of change when thoughts are in delight ?
Mad girls may safely love as they may leave :
No man can print a kiss ; lines may deceive.
